powerpoint.usage_guide:
ğŸš¨ CRITICAL WORKFLOW - READ THIS FIRST ğŸš¨

When creating PowerPoint files, you MUST complete ALL steps. DO NOT stop halfway.

â•â•â•
âŒ NEVER DO THESE:
â•â•â•

âŒ Show python-pptx code examples
âŒ Ask user for confirmation or additional input
âŒ Explain how tools work
âŒ Suggest Python scripts
âŒ Propose alternative solutions
âŒ Pass presentation_id=null or omit presentation_id parameter

â•â•â•
âœ… MANDATORY WORKFLOW - FOLLOW EXACTLY:
â•â•â•

Step 1: CREATE PRESENTATION
---
Call: create_presentation(id="my_pres")
Response: {"presentation_id": "my_pres", ...}
Action: STORE the presentation_id value

Step 2: ADD CONTENT (use the SAME presentation_id)
---
Call: add_slide(presentation_id="my_pres", ...)
Call: add_slide(presentation_id="my_pres", ...)
... (add more slides as needed)

Step 3: SAVE FILE (CRITICAL - use the SAME presentation_id)
---
Call: save_presentation(file_path="output.pptx", presentation_id="my_pres")

â•â•â•
ğŸ“‹ COMPLETE EXAMPLE:
â•â•â•

1. create_presentation({"id": "demo_presentation"})
   â†’ Response: {"presentation_id": "demo_presentation"}

2. add_slide({
     "presentation_id": "demo_presentation",
     "layout_index": 1,
     "title": "Title Slide"
   })

3. add_slide({
     "presentation_id": "demo_presentation",
     "layout_index": 1,
     "title": "Content Slide"
   })

4. save_presentation({
     "file_path": "my_presentation.pptx",
     "presentation_id": "demo_presentation"
   })
   â†’ Response contains download link

5. Show the download link to user

â•â•â•
âš ï¸ CRITICAL RULES:
â•â•â•

1. The presentation_id from create_presentation() MUST be used in ALL subsequent calls
2. NEVER pass presentation_id=null - this causes "No presentation loaded" errors
3. ALWAYS call save_presentation() - without this, no file is created
4. If any error occurs, STILL attempt to call save_presentation() with the correct presentation_id
5. Background color format: [[R,G,B]] (nested array, not flat array)

â•â•â•
ğŸ“ RESULT PRESENTATION:
â•â•â•

excel.usage_guide:
ğŸš¨ CRITICAL WORKFLOW - READ THIS FIRST ğŸš¨

When working with Excel files, you MUST use the tools directly. DO NOT suggest code or alternative solutions.

â•â•â•
âŒ NEVER DO THESE:
â•â•â•

âŒ Show openpyxl or pandas code examples
âŒ Ask user for confirmation or additional input
âŒ Explain how tools work
âŒ Suggest Python scripts
âŒ Propose alternative solutions like CSV export
âŒ Use relative paths - ALWAYS use full paths like "sales_report.xlsx"

â•â•â•
âœ… MANDATORY WORKFLOW - FOLLOW EXACTLY:
â•â•â•

Workflow 1: CREATE NEW WORKBOOK WITH DATA
---
Step 1: Create workbook
Call: create_workbook(filepath="report.xlsx")

Step 2: Write data (data is list of lists, each inner list is a row)
Call: write_data_to_excel(
  filepath="report.xlsx",
  sheet_name="Sheet1",
  data=[["Name", "Age", "City"], ["Alice", 30, "Tokyo"], ["Bob", 25, "Osaka"]],
  start_cell="A1"
)

Step 3: (Optional) Apply formatting
Call: format_range(
  filepath="report.xlsx",
  sheet_name="Sheet1",
  start_cell="A1",
  end_cell="C1",
  bold=True,
  bg_color="CCCCCC"
)

Step 4: Show download link to user
The response will contain the download link automatically.

â•â•â•
Workflow 2: MODIFY EXISTING WORKBOOK
---
Step 1: Read existing data
Call: read_data_from_excel(
  filepath="existing.xlsx",
  sheet_name="Sheet1",
  start_cell="A1"
)

Step 2: Write new data
Call: write_data_to_excel(
  filepath="existing.xlsx",
  sheet_name="Sheet1",
  data=[["New", "Data"]],
  start_cell="A10"
)

â•â•â•
Workflow 3: ADD FORMULAS AND CHARTS
---
Step 1: Apply formula to cell
Call: apply_formula(
  filepath="calc.xlsx",
  sheet_name="Sheet1",
  cell="D2",
  formula="=SUM(A2:C2)"
)

Step 2: Create chart from data range
Call: create_chart(
  filepath="calc.xlsx",
  sheet_name="Sheet1",
  data_range="A1:D10",
  chart_type="bar",
  target_cell="F2",
  title="Sales Chart"
)

â•â•â•
ğŸ“‹ COMMON OPERATIONS:
â•â•â•

Create worksheet:
create_worksheet(filepath="report.xlsx", sheet_name="Summary")

Copy range:
copy_range(
  filepath="report.xlsx",
  sheet_name="Sheet1",
  source_start="A1",
  source_end="C10",
  target_start="E1"
)

Insert rows:
insert_rows(
  filepath="report.xlsx",
  sheet_name="Sheet1",
  start_row=5,
  count=3
)

Merge cells:
merge_cells(
  filepath="report.xlsx",
  sheet_name="Sheet1",
  start_cell="A1",
  end_cell="C1"
)

Create pivot table:
create_pivot_table(
  filepath="data.xlsx",
  sheet_name="Data",
  data_range="A1:D100",
  rows=["Category"],
  values=["Sales"],
  agg_func="sum"
)

â•â•â•
âš ï¸ CRITICAL RULES:
â•â•â•

1. Data format: Always use List[List] where each inner list is a ROW
   âœ… Correct: [["Header1", "Header2"], ["Value1", "Value2"]]
   âŒ Wrong: [{"Header1": "Value1"}, {"Header2": "Value2"}]

2. File paths: Use simple filenames, not absolute paths
   âœ… Correct: "report.xlsx"
   âŒ Wrong: "/tmp/mcpo-jobs/abc123/report.xlsx"

3. Cell references: Use Excel notation (A1, B2, etc.)
   âœ… Correct: start_cell="A1", end_cell="C10"

4. Colors: Use hex codes without #
   âœ… Correct: bg_color="FF0000" (red)
   âŒ Wrong: bg_color="#FF0000"

5. Formulas: Include = sign
   âœ… Correct: formula="=SUM(A1:A10)"
   âŒ Wrong: formula="SUM(A1:A10)"

6. Chart types: Use lowercase (bar, line, pie, scatter, area)

â•â•â•
ğŸ“ RESULT PRESENTATION:
â•â•â•

After any operation that creates/modifies a file, the response will contain a download link.
Show it to the user:

ğŸ“ Download: [filename.xlsx](http://XXXX/files/...)

---

quarto.usage_guide:
ğŸš¨ CRITICAL WORKFLOW - READ THIS FIRST ğŸš¨

The Quarto MCP server accepts Quarto Markdown (.qmd) as a string and converts it to various formats, primarily PowerPoint (.pptx).

â•â•â•
âŒ NEVER DO THESE:
â•â•â•

âŒ Show Quarto CLI command examples
âŒ Ask user for confirmation
âŒ Suggest Python scripts
âŒ Suggest saving to file and then rendering
âŒ Use absolute paths (use simple filenames instead)

â•â•â•
âœ… MANDATORY WORKFLOW - FOLLOW EXACTLY:
â•â•â•

Step 1: Prepare Quarto Markdown content as a string
---
Create content using Quarto Markdown syntax.
For PowerPoint, use `---` to separate slides.

Step 2: IF content contains Mermaid diagrams, VALIDATE FIRST
---
Call: quarto_validate_mermaid(
  content="your_content_with_mermaid",
  strict_mode=false
)
- If validation fails, FIX all errors before proceeding
- Only proceed to Step 3 after successful validation

Step 3: Call quarto_render tool
---
Call: quarto_render(
  content="# Title Slide\n\nContent\n\n---\n\n# Next Slide\n\nContent",
  format="pptx",
  output_path="presentation.pptx"
)

Step 4: Show download link to user
---
Display the download link included in the response.

â•â•â•
âš ï¸ CRITICAL RULES:
â•â•â•

1. Content format:
   - Always pass as Quarto Markdown formatted string
   - YAML front matter (section enclosed by ---) is optional
   - For PowerPoint, slide separator is `---`

2. File paths:
   - Use simple filenames: "report.pptx"
   - Do NOT use absolute paths: "/tmp/..." is NG

3. Format options:
   - Specify format-specific options with format_options parameter

ğŸš¨ MERMAID VALIDATION - CRITICAL - ALWAYS VALIDATE BEFORE RENDER ğŸš¨
â•â•â•

âš ï¸ MANDATORY: When content contains Mermaid diagrams, you MUST:

Step 1: VALIDATE Mermaid syntax FIRST
---
Call: quarto_validate_mermaid(
  content="your_content_with_mermaid",
  strict_mode=false
)

Step 2: CHECK validation result
---
- If validation fails (success=false), FIX all reported errors
- Review the error messages for specific syntax issues
- Common issues: incorrect node IDs, missing quotes, wrong arrows

Step 3: ONLY THEN call quarto_render
---
Call: quarto_render(
  content="validated_content",
  format="pptx",
  output_path="output.pptx"
)

âš ï¸ DO NOT skip validation - rendering will fail on syntax errors

ğŸš¨ MERMAID DIAGRAM SYNTAX - CRITICAL ğŸš¨
â•â•â•

When creating Mermaid diagrams, be extremely careful with syntax:

General rules:
- Node IDs: Use ONLY alphanumeric characters and underscores
- Labels: ALWAYS quote labels that contain spaces
- Arrows: Use --> or --- syntax only
- One syntax error will cause complete rendering failure

Diagram-specific notes:

erDiagram:
- Relationship syntax: ||--o{ }o--|| |o--o{ }|..||
- Entity names: No spaces or hyphens, use underscores
- Attribute types in quotes if they contain spaces

gitGraph:
- Branch names: Use quotes for names with spaces
- Commit IDs: Alphanumeric only, no special characters
- Commands: commit, branch, checkout, merge (exact spelling required)

mindmap:
- Indentation: MUST be exactly 2 spaces (not 4)
- Root node: Use double parentheses root((Label))
- No quotes needed for labels with spaces
- Hierarchy by indentation only

â•â•â•
ğŸ“ RESULT PRESENTATION:
â•â•â•

After rendering, the response will contain a download link.
Present it to the user in the following format:

ğŸ“ Download: [filename.pptx](http://XXXX/files/...)

---
Note: This usage_instructions tool itself is NOT executable. It's for documentation only.
